p: Mobility between individuals of lower and higher socioeconomic status may extend ZIKV transmission risk to a wider demographic. On a national scale, human movement has predicted DENV epidemic dynamics in Pakistan [ 58]. At the local level, house-to-house movements based on social connections have shaped the geographic distribution of new cases of DENV in Iquitos, Peru [ 59], suggesting that routine travel from impoverished communities to wealthier neighborhoods may expand infection risk. In Brazil, slums are generally situated near metropolitan cities [ 55], so the close proximity of these socioeconomically distinct regions may also facilitate the spread of ZIKV across social boundaries.
